translated: Jātaka
Pañcakanipāta
Maṇikuṇḍalavagga
The Laṭukikā Jātaka
“I pay homage to you, elephant, who travels sixty leagues,
The famous leader of the herd in the forest;
I raise my wings in respectful salutation to you,
Don’t kill my young ones, I’m so weak.”
“I pay homage to you, elephant, who travels alone,
The forest-dwelling one whose range is the mountains;
I raise my wings in respectful salutation to you,
Don’t kill my young ones, I’m so weak.”
“I’ll kill your young ones, Laṭukikā,

analyzed: kim me tuvam kā ahasi dubbalā asi
translated: What can you do, you’re so weak?
Even a hundred thousand like you
I’d crush with my left foot.”

analyzed: na ha iva sabbattha balena kittha
translated: “Not everywhere is strength effective,
For the strength of a fool is for his own destruction.
I’ll do you harm, king of elephants,
For you killed my young ones, I’m so weak.”
“Look at the crow and the Laṭukikā,
The frog and the bluebottle fly;
They killed the elephant,
See the enemy of an enemy;
Therefore one should not make an enemy,
and by some one else who is not related to him.”
The Jātaka of the Herb-seller (seventh of the series).
